sentence: Typically the Memento pattern is used to implement roll-back/save point support .
tag_sequence: O O B-Algorithm I-Algorithm O O O O O O O O

sentence: For example I might want to mark the state of an object at a point in time , do some work and then decide to revert that object back to the point at which is was marked .

sentence: The implementation of a Memento pattern could use serialisation , which would involve saving the contents of the object into a byte[] and keeping in memory or writing to disk .
tag_sequence: O O O O B-Algorithm I-Algorithm O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-Data_Structure O O O O O O O B-Device O

sentence: When reverting the content of the object would be rebuilt from the serialised copy .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Conversely I could implement a Memento pattern by cloning the object in memory and keeping a reference to the copy and then copying the state back if the object needs reverting .

sentence: I have multiple clients who can view the plane through rectangular viewports .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Each client 's viewport may be of different dimensions , and can be moved instantly to any location on the plane .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The clients do not know the locations of the points ; only the server does .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: When a client connects , it will communicate the size of its viewport to the server , and the server should respond with a location where one or more points will be visible to that client 's viewport .

sentence: This continues until all points have been visited by at least one client .

tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: In an object-oriented language , you send messages to objects and those objects then respond to those messages however they see fit .

sentence: This means that the receiver of the message , and only the receiver(!)

sentence: Here 's an example : if you write your own Numeric class ( say , a Quaternion class ) , then the system builtin Fixnum class does n't know anything about Quaternions . So , when you ask the Fixnum 0 whether it is equal to the Quaternion ( 0 , 0 , 0 , 0 ) , it will responds false , even though that 's wrong .

sentence: After all , the Quaternion class did n't exist when the Fixnum class was written , so the Fixnum class cannot know about Quaternions . But when the Quaternion class was written , maybe the author was so thoughtful to make it possible to compare Quaternions with Fixnums .

sentence: In Ruby , classes are n't types and subtyping and subclassing are different .

sentence: Ruby itself does n't have a concept of type at all !
tag_sequence: B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The type of an object is its protocol , i.e . the messages it understands and how it responds to them .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: But that concept is not recorded in Ruby ( unlike Objective-C , for example , which does have an explicit notion of protocol ) .

sentence: There , however , some cases , where you want to break OO encapsulation , and know the specific type and even more : the specific representation of the type .

sentence: ( Note : this violates OO , but it is sometimes necessary for performance . )
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: In cases , where Ruby needs an object to be of a specific class instead of just responding to a specific protocol , you would lose a lot of flexibility .
tag_sequence: O O O O B-Language O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: You have to use , say , a String , even though you would much rather use a Rope instead .
tag_sequence: O O O O O O O O B-Data_Type O O O O O O O O O B-Data_Type O O

sentence: In order to give you back some flexibility , Ruby allows you to pass in something which is not exactly a String but which is equivalent to one and can be converted to one with a to_str method .
